So the interest expense increase is just right and that will continue, because rates have gone up and we've had to refinance, but it's not huge. I mean it's sort of tens of millions of dollars. Now, the FTE – let me talk about redundancy.

Redundancy, we spent $160 million in the first half. We don't expect to spend that much. Remember in the second half – remember I said the total redundancy expenditure is likely to be 220 also in the full year, we'll be around about that mark, maybe a little bit more. We will time our redundancies perfectly, but it's not going to be anywhere near the first half redundancies, and I said, we're front-end loaded in our exits of – you're right, the exits where 700 or so in net terms and there will still be some exits in the second half, but not at the same rate.
That tax rate, John, will that be 33% for the full year as well?
It might come down a little.
Okay. Thank you.
Maybe now towards the 30%.

Right. Let me just – I want to come back to just labor and labor sub, because it's not just the head count, it's about labor and labor sub and we have a lot of focus on that. So I am expecting it to continue to decline and that's what we've got to do as a business. Been years we've got some redundancy costs, but the only result here is to drive a more efficient business. So every business unit has targets to continue drive efficiency. So it must come down. Now, there's mixtures in the FTE numbers, there's some contractors and agency staff, it's everything that's out for grabs, so a lot of work going on.
Christian?
Good morning. Just on mobile, in particular, iPad customers. Are iPad customers a material number for you guys? And if they are, are they classified as mobile broadband, or just purely in handheld?
John, you've got to help me here. Let me...
I'll answer that. They're classified as prepaid mobile broadband.

Yeah. And the number of iPads is – it's on the top of my tongue – Gordon, can you remember? It's about 70,000, yeah. I think it was – and Galaxy is not as many, but going okay. But the ARPUs are, yeah, not anyway near what we get, means sort of in the low, low numbers. So we can get to the data on it, but if we watch that – it's a emerging category that because people go into WiFi a lot, what you get on the 3G networks don't quite want to go. Okay.
Given that it's kind of mobile broadband ARPU is around $40 now. As these other segments grow, we could probably see ARPUs trending even lower given those lower price points?

Yeah, what we're doing now is – and the ARPU story is getting more and more complicated, because we're also getting a lot of machine-to-machine and that can be based low as $5 ARPU. Then you're getting the tablet category, then you've got just the straight mobile phone, then you've got a smartphone and different types of smartphones. So, while we may be seeing overall ARPU declines the actual cost to sell – fairly every category has got a different equation. So what we'll do is we can get you that data, because that's a lot of the work we're doing now as we start to move into these new areas, which is going to continue to grow the number of so called subscribers on the wireless network.

And just a related question around mobile CapEx, in particular. Obviously you've got 0.5 million new wireless broadband customers. Obviously data utilization is increasing. I mean can you give us a feel for how that's tracking and how the network is going? Obviously, your competitors have been spending a lot outside of the floods, having to spend a lot for various reasons, but how is Telstra's network?

The network is going – holding up incredibly well, both in terms of its performance, in terms of the headroom, still got a lot of headroom, in terms of the amount of data we can carry. Remember it's what I think, roughly, 90% data packets and 10% voice or around about there, but we are very pleased with the network and we have some good plans coming up too.
Okay, thanks.
And managing the CapEx well, and continue to drive coverage proposition and speed proposition. We are very pleased with the network.
Andrew?

Thanks. Andrew Levy, Macquarie. Your latest cap plans, well the cap plans when I looked appear to have an embedded MRO or Mobile Repayment Option charge in them, and John, you referred before when Sameer asked a question to greater Mobile Repayment Option takeup in the second half. That kind of sales technique, I guess, pools forward some of your revenues. So, I was just wondering if you could talk to when that was introduced, what the impact on the FY '11 accounts will be versus selling how you used to sell, and also what the ARPU impact will be in the medium term?

Yeah, we introduced zero MRO option in December and that has an impact on the revenue line. In that the phone is not subsidized and the cost of the handset is spread over revenues, or they're amortized over the contract period. So, as a result of that – and it's spread over hardware and usage, all right? So, it's one of the reasons that I mentioned that ARPUs will decline in the second half, because rather than subsidy it has a net revenue or an impact on your credit. So, that's how that works. So you come in and buy a handset on a zero MRO plan, meaning your handset doesn't cost you anything, but it's in an accounting sense the sales are amortized over the revenue contract period offsetting its usage and hardware sales.
So the sale is recognized on the day one or the sales is recognized over 24 months, just so I have more clarity?
Well we make the sale on a day, but the accounting is that the revenue declines over 24 months, it's amortized 24 months.
Thanks. Thank you.

Just wanted to go back to the comment you made on the documentation. You think I am going to – I think – I'm upset with the timing, but it is, we've been in a sort of information void in terms of real NBN disclosure from that eight months, so it's kind of getting a little long. And two months documentation process. Not sure what law firm you use, but that seems to be an awful long time to put these documents together. I'm sure they can do much better than that. And so, is the idea that you actually – you are waiting to have the legislation through, because you don't want to add to the current controversy by releasing more detail on your definitive agreements? I'm struggling with the timing of the increased disclosure?
Let me think about the question. No, we're not waiting for any legislation. Do you deal with lawyers?
Unfortunately yes.
We love them daily and they are quite good.

Then we shouldn't – we shouldn't underestimate the complexity of this agreement. I've been up to my armpits in the whole thing and we shouldn't underestimate the importance of what we've said today. I know it's easy to say, well you haven't told us much new about NBN today? But to actually agree the deal terms is really the blue print for the lawyers to go document. Why we haven't gone any further than we have is that we haven't been in that position.

We've been still talking about the deal terms Telstra to NBN, and for that matter the elements of the government contract that will emerge between Telstra and the government. So, that really sets the blue print for the lowers to go away and do the documentation. Now, having said that, that doesn't mean that that doesn't have its own complexity, because – but I just want to make sure people understand here that where we have got to and what we've been asked today is an important milestone, because the blue print is there for the documentation.
Actually what documents – have you signed a document with NBN Co? Have you signed a term sheet, have you signed something that binds your organization into the documentation process?
We have agreed the deal terms on an exchange of letters.

Exchange of letters, okay. And second question, thanks for that clarification, it's very useful. Second question is around the interaction between your volume re-acceleration and the impact that it's had on ARPU. Particularly if you had to kind of go back and look at the last six months in terms of how you've driven the volume re-acceleration in mobile and fixed broadband, what would you say has been the most important sort of driver in terms of how you've driven that subscriber growth? And what – back off of my mind it's from my point of view I think you've driven that a lot more through the cost. So your cost to re-investment rather than an actual price gap, but I'm interested to have your view on it?

Well, I think it's really a mixture of all the above. I mean, remember, what, nine months ago some of our plants had 35% premiums on them. So, I think that we were not as competitive as we need to be. We weren't as strong in some of the smartphones as we needed to be, and then I think also our promotion wasn't quite where it needed to be. So, as you'd understand, it's the balance between all the above and getting the channel working correctly.

And I think we've just had a really good mix of that and we have been very conscious not to start a price war, because we don't believe that's in anyone interest but we did want to make sure that we were having attractive plans with the right handsets at the right level. So that's been a lot of the work we've done and I think we've got a bit of management of it on a weekly, monthly basis roller on. So, I put that down to that. John, do you want to add any more to that?
No, I think it's exactly right.
Very finally one, just on the PCP -
Yeah.
So looking at postpaid, mobile down marginal sort of 1%, fixed broadband down marginally 1.7%.
Yeah.
Is that the sort of PCP run rate you're thinking of taking into second half or there will be a bit of an acceleration on the PCP rate, in terms of ARPU compression?
Well, I have already mentioned the MRO impact on the mobile ARPU, and so it will be a little more than 1.7%.
Just a little bit more. But with the strong volume and the right customer mix coming through, I think that that's where we feel confident.
Thank you.

We'll take one more – we haven't got time, so we will take one more question here, and I know that Digby and Christian have been on the line waiting for a while. So we'll come back to the phone lines. Andrew?

Thanks. Yeah. Andrew Anagnostellis, Deutsche. Just on the PSTN business, it's a reality that it is declining, but are you disappointed with the rate of decline in the last half given all the new products you've introduced? And just philosophically, going forward, in an NBN world does this business just continue to run off or is there some sort of strategy to either accelerate or slow the decline?

No, we're not disappointed, it's pretty much where we expect it to be. You can see from the bundling strategy in some of the PSTN access pricing whereas we're rebalancing. And what I'll do is I'll get John to take you through just a little bit of the mix in the PSTN, because you got to look at access and calling rates. And John, did you bring those numbers over here?
Yeah. I have got the numbers. It's already in my head anyway.
Yeah, thank you.

I mean it's driven by usage, as I think I said and people are just using other mobile and Facebook to communicate and as I told you, SMS is all and so on. So of the – access is sort of a highest element of the PSTN revenues and that declined about 4%, right. So the line reduction is not too bad. So people actually having an access line. But it's – the 8.4% is driven by like 20% reduction in local calls and another 13% in national long distance, they are the sort of numbers that are driving the 8.4%, so it's usage again, right.

But access lines, access revenues, access revenue reduction of 4.4, I think it's – so that's sort of the mix that's going on. I guess that will continue as people continue to use other forms of communication and access lines will gradually will come off, but in the brave new NBN world it will be quite a different – voice will probably be an application of that – who knows how much it will be charged for – or we'll charge them different.

Just in terms of – the whole reason you're doing this strategy is of course to restore earnings growth. Clearly, this year it's not happening. I mean what confidence should investors have that the measures we're seeing this year are going to translate into earnings growth next year? I mean obviously we don't expect a formal guidance, but just perhaps in terms of some of the revenue and cost drivers that could flow through to next year?

I think 1 million users is a pretty good proof point, but as I showed in my chart, about revenues returning and growth and also in terms of profitability. But you also need to look at the fundamentals. Yes, we have invested around customer growth, which we told you we're going to do, we told you what was going to happen this year and it's all about returning to topline growth and profit growth.

Now with the cost out you see the labor improving. Yes, there is some variable cost increase, but that's good investment, good investment. You're getting returns in 10, 11 months, it's – that's very good. So, I think that's the proof point and so the momentum in the business is very strong and we're going to keep it going, because it's a good thing for our shareholders.

And the simplification of the business, I and Robert told you all of it. There's time that had to be spent and has been spent on identifying all the opportunities and that's been done and now we're into execution on those, doing certain projects that Dave mentioned, to have a totally different cost base in our organization – lower.
That's why you should feel comfortable.
Thanks.
We'll just go the phone lines for two last questions. I think we've got Digby.
Yes, we have Digby wishing to ask another question. Please go ahead, Digby.

Okay. Thanks for coming back to me. Just quickly, two questions actually. NBN cash flows, John, within your assumptions what proportion of the 11 billion NPV will be realized before the next election, so I call it about a year-end FY '13, so in other words what extent do you think long guided supply contracts or contract to service arrangements will provide certainty over the remaining cash flows, if there is a change in government? And then very quickly, another question, Yellow Pages, the 18% decline in adjusted print revenues, can you please give us some indication there? You've indicated higher cancellations and a declining yield, so what was the volume and yield mix within that 18% print decline? Thank you.
You take NBN?

Yeah, I can. The first challenge is picking when the next election will be. Look, if we talk about election being three years out, remember, in the first three years, the cash flows from the NBN arrangements aren't going to be great, right. So – but in term – and the cash flows come from the infrastructure leasing and so they're not going to be doing a hell of a lot of work in the first three years. And therefore the other element of cash flows that come to the company, which is payment for de-commissioning customers also won't be very much in the next three years. So, cash flows in the next – if we assume elections in three years time, might be very high over the next three-year period.
And in terms of Sensis – now Bruce Akhurst is in Melbourne? Bruce, you there? What's up?
He is not on the phone.
Bruce is not there?
He is not on the phone, yeah.

Okay. So what I think will be based on the – because the Yellow is – there's a number of different numbers you got to look at it across print and digital. What I think we'll do is come back and we can give you some more color on that, because I think that's a longer story. But I understand what you're driving to, and something we're looking. So, we'll come back on that one, Digby.
Christian, I think, you are back on.

I also have a couple of follow-up questions. The first one is on your labor cost growth expectations for FY '12. My second question, John, is just touch on something that you mentioned earlier about, sorry, it was you David on your plans for the mobiles network. I was just wondering what that means to you CapEx expectations for the company for FY '12? And then thirdly just touching on something that Digby mentioned. You obviously sort of talked that went over the last six or seven months around the $11 billion number and that's something that obviously shareholders are very focused on. What sort of strategies do you have in place to mitigate the risk of NBN not getting to sort of 90%, 93% coverage in terms of what that means to your total compensation package?

Right, let me answer the second one on any plans we have within the wireless network is just within the normal CapEx unplugged. So, no additional CapEx you should be planning for at all. In terms of the NBN Co, that you are on exactly right sorts of questions, Christians, so it doesn't get too nice – what does that mean, that's why there is a lot of discussion that you need to have about what that means. And of course, the implications of when exchanges are turned off, not turned off, all those sort of things are critically important, in fact, probably more important than is apparent from just what people think you're doing in that topline deal. In terms of labor cost for the second half of the year, John?

Well, I think, Christian asked about fiscal year '12. And we're not really guiding on fiscal year '12, Christian. To your CapEx question and that was a fiscal year '12 question as well, and I'm not saying this is fiscal year '12 but in over next three or four years, we will have a spectrum renewal requirement and so that will add to our CapEx requirement, but that's sort of fiscal year '13 and beyond.
But nothing in terms of...
Other operators will have their requirements.

Yeah, that's right. So I think that's been pretty much rated, but in terms of my comment about what we're doing, there's no additional CapEx, which was why the question was asked. Okay. So, does that answer your question, Christian?
Right, thank you very much. All right, thanks. Very good.
Okay.
Thank you, there's no more questions. I'll hand back to David if he's got any closing words.
You know we've got the right momentum where we're going well and we look forward to finishing the year strongly. Thanks very much.
